awd_titl_txt: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH:  Jurors' Use of Scientific Information
awd_abstract_narration:
Juries often rely on and interpret evidence based on scientific research when making decisions in civil and criminal cases. The validity and reliability of scientific information varies, yet jurors generally are non-experts who do not possess the necessary tools to differentiate between weak and strong scientific information when making decisions. To assess the issue of interpretation of scientific evidence in court, this project uses an experimental approach to examine jurors' ability to interpret and act on scientific evidence. To do so, this project consists of jury simulations that will examine jurors' and juries' sensitivity to strong versus weak scientific information presented in court. 

The project includes two jury simulation experiments designed to test whether fuzzy trace theory, a well-developed theory in cognitive science, applies in the context of jury research, particularly when compared to other safeguards for jury decision making with respect to scientific evidence. This multidisciplinary, multi-method research will examine when and how jurors' inferences are appropriately calibrated to the strength of scientific information, whether a safeguard derived from decision-making theory can improve that calibration, and how various measures relevant to the processing of scientific information are related to one another. The project addresses fundamental questions about how humans reason with and make inferences and decisions based on the quality of relevant scientific data.

por.por_cntn:
Juries are increasingly being asked to interpret scientific evidence when making decisions in civil and criminal cases. It is unclear, however, whether they are able to distinguish between weak and strong scientific evidence when rendering decisions. In this project, we sought to answer whether juror decision-making is accurately calibrated to the strength of scientific information presented in civil and criminal trials. We also examined whether some jurors, such as those who are good with numbers or have strong scientific reasoning skills, might be better at distinguishing between weak and strong scientific evidence at trial. Finally, we considered whether a decision aid that visually conveyed the gist of the scientific information would help jurors distinguish between weak and strong scientific evidence.

 

To achieve these objectives, we conducted two jury simulation experiments with diverse community participants at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln and Arizona State University. Mock juror participants watched a realistic video with professional actors depicting a civil trial with neuroimaging evidence (Experiment 1) or a criminal trial with DNA evidence (Experiment 2). In both experiments, jurors received weak or strong scientific evidence. Some jurors also received a decision aid, based on fuzzy trace theory, that visually depicted the gist of the neuroimaging (Experiment 1) or DNA (Experiment 2) evidence while others received standard safeguards already used in the courts (e.g., jury instructions from the judge). Finally, personality and cognitive differences among jurors were assessed in both experiments. 

Data analysis for this project is ongoing. To date, we have discovered that jurors are somewhat sensitive to the quality of scientific evidence presented at civil and criminal trials. In particular, jurors who are good with numbers and have strong scientific reasoning skills are better able to distinguish between weak and strong evidence; they were more aware of the differences in evidence quality, understood the evidence better, and importantly discussed the scientific evidence more with other jurors during deliberation. Interestingly, the decision aid did not appear to appropriately calibrate jurors to the strength of the scientific evidence. 

These results suggest that juries may appropriately calibrate scientific information presented in civil and criminal trials, especially when individual jurors are high in numeracy and scientific reasoning. Additionally, this project provided educational and learning opportunities to new scientists, thereby increasing the scientific workforce. In the interest making science more replicable, robust, and transparent, Experiment 1 and Experiment 2 were preregistered and all data files and materials are or will be available on the Open Science Framework website (https://osf.io).
